source.absolute_timeline_notes: Continuation inside Core Medical Archive 17B, Sector 4; Shelly conducts a forensic first pass on Specimen 291874237 (Randy).

text_windows.full_scene_clean: The pod rises with a hiss; cold mist curls across the vault floor as seals disengage. Lights adjust. Randy lies in the capsule, preserved yet ruined: paper-thin skin, collapsed cheeks, jutting clavicles, curled fingers. Shelly steadies herself, then triggers her prepared FI-III checklist overlay via PID. She begins First Pass: visual inspection against a baseline wireframe. Amber and red flags populate, including pressure ulcers inconsistent with regulated pod care. Shelly orders a full panel—neurochemistry, tox, musculoskeletal, endocrine—and behavioral sync to biometric logs. Insectile probes sweep; Stella’s toolkit renders a neurochemical deviation map: extreme cortisol spikes, dopamine instability, severe serotonin drop, brainstem alert, and rapid-onset cachexia. PID logs (Level III; personal entries redacted) show incongruously calm neurochems. Cross-checking timestamps returns 27 misaligned entries and a probable data falsification alert. Shelly classifies the case as Potential Malpractice/Intent to Harm, freezes records, and initializes an audit trail with an indefinite cadaver hold. She sends a secure message to her father, Lucas, noting forged neuroject logs and that Randy’s death was not a simple decline. She ends the session, returns the subject to storage, and vows to find the perpetrators.
text_windows.dense_recap_250w: In the Sector 4 vault of Core Medical Archive 17B, Shelly begins a structured FI-III cadaver exam on Specimen 291874237—Randy, her 18-year-old brother. A PID-driven checklist and Stella’s forensic toolkit overlay a baseline wireframe and launch a full panel of internal analyses. Visual flags include pressure ulcers that imply prolonged immobility inconsistent with medical failsafes. Neurochemical deviation mapping shows catastrophic cortisol spikes, dopamine instability, steep serotonin depletion, a brainstem alert, and rapid-onset cachexia—signs of acute neurochemical collapse rather than stable decline. When Shelly opens the Level III neuroject logs (personal entries redacted), they depict a calm, pleasurable state. She cross-checks the logs against real-time biofeedback and receives 27 timestamp misalignments and a probable data-falsification alert, indicating synthetic or manipulated entries. Concluding that someone accessed Randy’s neuroject and shut him down while forging logs, Shelly updates classification to Potential Malpractice/Intent to Harm, freezes the record, and places an indefinite hold on the cadaver with an audit trail. She sends a terse, secure update to her father, Lucas, and privately vows to find whoever is responsible. The session ends with Randy returned to storage and Shelly walking out, resolved.

Visual and internal scans show pressure ulcers, catastrophic neurochemical collapse, and rapid cachexia. Level III neuroject logs contradict the biofeedback; cross-checks reveal 27 misaligned entries and probable falsification. Shelly freezes the case, places an indefinite hold, starts an audit, informs her father, and vows to find the culprits.
